required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Acute Effects of an Herbal Tea on Immune Surveillance and Activation.
clinical_study.official_title: Acute Effects of an Herbal Tea Blend on Immune Surveillance and Activation Status of Natural Killer Cells.

brief_summary.textblock: A small cross-over trial on 24 people involving an herbal tea blend to test whether consuming 1 cup of tea triggers changes in the numbers of natural killer cells in the blood circulation as evidence of immune cell trafficking within 2 hours.

detailed_description.textblock: A randomized, cross-over, controlled study design will be used to evaluate the effects of consumption of 1 cup of an herbal tea blend to consumption of the same volume of warm water. The study is of 3 weeks' duration, with evaluation of the herbal tea blend versus warm water at week 1 and week 2 with a one week washout between visits. On each visit, a baseline blood draw is performed, followed by consuming of the herbal tea blend or warm water. Blood draws are performed at 1 and 2 hours after consumption.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: The study uses a randomized double-blinded controlled cross-over study design.

primary_outcome.measure: Change to natural killer cell numbers in blood circulation
primary_outcome.time_frame: Changes at 1 and 2 hours after consumption
primary_outcome.description: Flow cytometry evaluation of natural killer cell numbers

secondary_outcome.measure: Change to natural killer cell activation status
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Changes at 1 and 2 hours after consumption
secondary_outcome.description: Flow cytometry evaluation of CD69 expression on natural killer cells in the blood circulation

arm_group.description: 1 cup of herbal tea blend containing Rosehip and other berry extracts.

intervention.description: 1 cup of freshly brewed tea from an herbal tea blend.
